meaning_mnemonic:
Something's <kanji>effective</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is its <vocabulary>effectiveness</vocabulary>. If it has effective power, it remains <vocabulary>in effect</vocabulary>.

This word usually refers to the legal force or effectiveness of a law, agreement, contract, or treaty, but it can also be used to talk about the efficacy of other things, such as medicine.

<kanji>Again</kanji> you <kanji>build</kanji> it. This is <vocabulary>rebuilding</vocabulary>.

再建 is a formal word that refers to the act of rebuilding something that has deteriorated or been lost, whether it's a physical structure like a building or an organization, or a part of the body in the context of medical procedures.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>get a position</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get a position</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get a job</vocabulary>.

Note that 就く is used with another word that indicates a position or a job, like 王位に就く(becoming a king) or 仕事に就く (finding employment).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ascend</kanji> so the verb vocab version must be <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>.

昇る is commonly used to talk about things like the sun and the moon rising, or smoke rising from a fire.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

It's common to see this word written in kanji, but you'll also see it written in hiragana, especially in casual contexts.

What's that feeling when your <kanji>belly</kanji> <kanji>stands</kanji> up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means <vocabulary>to get mad</vocabulary>.

If your <kanji>abdomen</kanji> is getting <kanji>cut</kanji>, and you're the one doing the cutting, there's a good chance you're committing <vocabulary>harakiri</vocabulary>, a form of <vocabulary>ritual suicide</vocabulary>.

腹切り sounds blunt and colloquial compared to the more formal 切腹. Kind of like you're just saying the words "belly cutting" — not very refined! This is often the case with synonym pairs like this: the one with kun'yomi readings will sound more casual, while the one with on'yomi readings will sound more formal.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>invite</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary>.

誘う refers to casually inviting someone to a place, an event, or an activity. If it's an invitation to something tempting, it can also mean <vocabulary>to tempt</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to entice</vocabulary>.

We work at the <kanji>same</kanji> place and are <kanji>colleague</kanji>s, making us <vocabulary>colleague</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>coworker</vocabulary>s.

As you might guess from the 同 kanji, 同僚 generally refers to people working in the same workplace with the same rank or status. In other words, you wouldn't usually call your boss your 同僚!

A <kanji>government</kanji> <kanji>colleague</kanji> is someone who works for the <vocabulary>bureaucracy</vocabulary>, making them a <vocabulary>bureaucrat</vocabulary>.

Just like the word bureaucracy in English, 官僚 often carries a negative connotation, suggesting red tape, inefficiency, or the power and influence that senior civil servants might wield within the government.

A <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>lady</kanji> is a lady who's in charge of a house. In other words, she's a <vocabulary>housewife</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>homemaker</vocabulary>! In Japan, this is a pretty common profession for married ladies, although things have been changing little by little. Still, being a housewife means you control the money, which is pretty neat if you ask me.

To <kanji>diagnose</kanji> is to (metaphorically) <kanji>cut off</kanji> all the possibilities you don't believe to be likely. That's how you get a <vocabulary>diagnosis</vocabulary>!

診断 is primarily used in medical contexts to mean the act of <vocabulary>diagnosing</vocabulary> or the diagnosis itself. In non-medical contexts, it can also mean an <vocabulary>assessment</vocabulary> used to evaluate something, like a 性格診断 (personality test).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji>, so this verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. You're not doing the drying here — it's happening on its own. To remember this, just think about how <reading>coo</reading>l (く) it is that something can become dry all by itself. It's just, like, the magic of nature — how cool is that?

The <kanji>dry</kanji> <kanji>seasons</kanji> is the <vocabulary>dry season</vocabulary>.

乾季 is a formal term typically used in geographical climate discussions, especially for regions with clear wet and dry seasons like Southeast Asia, Africa, and South America.

You <kanji>dry</kanji> out your <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> after saying <vocabulary>Kanpai</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>cheers</vocabulary>!

乾杯 means <vocabulary>toast</vocabulary>ing with your drink and is how you say "Cheers!" in Japanese. It literally means "dry your cup" (drink up), so traditionally, people would finish their drink after saying it. But it's much more relaxed nowadays—most people just take a sip for 乾杯.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.

促す means <vocabulary>to encourage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prompt</vocabulary> someone to take action or proceed with something. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to promote</vocabulary> the growth, development, or change of something.

I'm so for this I'm willing to <kanji>sponsor</kanji> you. I am going to <kanji>urge</kanji> you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great <vocabulary>urge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>press for</vocabulary> you to do this!

When you <kanji>sponsor</kanji> an <kanji>announce</kanji>ment, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> for all those they want to get in contact with.

催告 refers to the act of <vocabulary>officially notifying</vocabulary> someone with a <vocabulary>formal notice</vocabulary>, urging them to take action within a specified time frame. It's a technical term mainly used in legal or business contexts, like reminding someone to fulfill obligations such as payments or contracts.

The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>sponsor</kanji> for an event is the host who's <vocabulary>hosting</vocabulary> (and possibly sponsoring) it. 

主催 is a formal term often used in business, official events, or public gatherings. While it can imply sponsorship, it mainly refers to the act of leading and organizing an event or activity, as well as the person or group hosting it.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>break</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for the things you broke of theirs.

When <kanji>all</kanji> of something <kanji>breaks</kanji>, every last bit of it is broken. It's <vocabulary>complete destruction</vocabulary>!!!

全壊 is a formal term used when buildings or structures are completely destroyed by disasters like earthquakes, fires, or accidents. It's often seen in news reports or insurance assessments to describe the <vocabulary>total destruction</vocabulary> of property.

When something <kanji>collapse</kanji>s and <kanji>break</kanji>s, it is when a <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary> happens. Something big collapsing or <vocabulary>falling down</vocabulary> will probably result in its <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>.

倒壊 is a formal word often found in news or official documents. It's used to describe buildings or structures collapsing, usually from destructive forces like natural disasters or bombings.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

娘 primarily means <vocabulary>daughter</vocabulary> but can also refer to a <vocabulary>young woman</vocabulary> (often unmarried). This is because its original form is 産す女 (むすめ), or "a woman who gives birth." Over time, it came to represent both daughters and young women.
An "alone" (一人) <kanji>daughter</kanji> is a daughter with no other daughter siblings, making her the <vocabulary>only daughter</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>teach</kanji>ings are what makes up a <vocabulary>religion</vocabulary>. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
A <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>sect</kanji> is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a <vocabulary>sect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>denomination</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>zen</kanji> <kanji>religion</kanji> is a part of Buddhism. It is the <vocabulary>Zen sect</vocabulary> of Buddhism, or <vocabulary>Zen Buddhism</vocabulary>.

Practitioners of 禅宗 follow 禅 (Zen) practices like meditation and mindfulness to achieve enlightenment. That's why it's called 禅宗!

A <kanji>banquet</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing is when you meet together for a <vocabulary>banquet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dinner party</vocabulary>.

宴会 refers to a gathering where people share food and drinks to celebrate something or deepen their social bonds. It's generally not used for casual dinner parties among friends, but rather for formal or semi-formal social events involving a larger group of people, such as farewell parties for colleagues or workplace holiday parties.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

宴 is an old-fashioned word for 宴会. It refers to large, festive feasts in traditional settings, often involving lots of sake and the enjoyment of traditional performing arts. You may see it used in literature or in song lyrics to evoke scenes of grand, lavish banquets from ages past.
If 健康 is "health," then something that is <kanji>not</kanji> this is <vocabulary>unhealthy</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>tense</kanji> body begins to <kanji>stretch</kanji> tighter and tighter as <vocabulary>nervousness</vocabulary> takes over.

緊張 describes that nervousness you feel before a big event or during a stressful moment. It can also refer to other things that feel tight or strained, like muscle <vocabulary>tension</vocabulary>, or even global tensions and strained relations between countries.
This word looks a lot like 怒る, doesn't it? But this word isn't a verb, so you can think of it as referring to <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wrath</vocabulary> itself.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scary</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>.

怖い is commonly used in everyday language to describe something that's scary on a more immediate or personal level.
I <kanji>fear</kanji> it. It is <kanji>scary</kanji>. It is pure <vocabulary>terror</vocabulary>.

You learned 恐怖 means "terror," and 〜症 can mean "disease." So what's a terror disease? Well, it's a <vocabulary>phobia</vocabulary>.

In Japanese, 恐怖症 is mostly used as a suffix for specific phobia names, like 高所恐怖症 (acrophobia, or fear of heights). Do you have any 恐怖症?

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fear</kanji>? When you really feel fear, you think something is <vocabulary>terrifying</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frightening</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary>dreadful</vocabulary>.

恐ろしい can describe something that inspires deep fear or awe, often beyond normal feelings of fear. Since it can be used to create a dramatic or intense atmosphere, you might find 恐ろしい more often in literature.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> is equal to <vocabulary>one cup</vocabulary>. It could just be <vocabulary>a drink</vocabulary>, but if you're measuring exactly one cup, it needs to be <vocabulary>full</vocabulary> to the brim. That's <vocabulary>a lot</vocabulary> of liquid—so be careful not to spill!

一杯 mainly refers to the amount that fills a container, like a cup, glass, bowl, or even spoon. It can also describe something being "full," such as a full stomach or a theater at capacity (like how a cup is filled to the brim!). Depending on the context, it can also mean "a lot," as fullness implies abundance. When it uses that meaning, you'll also often see it written in just kana (いっぱい).

<kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>cups of liquid</kanji> is equals to <vocabulary>two cups</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>two drinks</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>two glasses</vocabulary>, depending on what your drink is in!

〜杯 is a counter used to count the amount that fills a container, such as a cup, glass, bowl, or even a spoon! The contents don't have to be liquid—you can use 二杯 for two bowls of rice or two spoons of sugar as well.

<kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>cups of liquid</kanji> is equals to <vocabulary>three cups</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>three drinks</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>three glasses</vocabulary> depending on what your drink is in!

〜杯 is a counter used to count the amount that fills a container, such as a cup, glass, bowl, or even a spoon! The contents don't have to be liquid—you can use 三杯 for three bowls of rice or three spoons of sugar as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

板 generally refers to something thin, flat, and solid, like a board, plank, slab, or plate. In some contexts, it can also refer to stock market boards that display trading prices, or bulletin boards used for posting messages in online forums.

A <kanji>watch over</kanji> <kanji>board</kanji> is a board that's put up and watches over everything. What kind of board watches over everything from up high? One that gets the most visibility, so probably a <vocabulary>signboard</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>billboard</vocabulary>.

看板 typically refers to physical signs, such as <vocabulary>store sign</vocabulary>s or billboards. But it can also mean the figurative symbol or face of a business, like 看板メニュー (signature dish) or 看板娘 (popular female employee).

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Get To The Bottom Of Something

meaning_mnemonic:
極める is "to carry to extremes." If you take the action of <kanji>see</kanji>ing something to the extremes, you're going <vocabulary>to get to the bottom of</vocabulary> whatever it is. You'll be able <vocabulary>to identify something</vocabulary>, like the truth.

見極める primarily involves the careful examination and discernment of the underlying aspects or truth of a matter. It emphasizes the thoroughness and effort required to make well-informed decisions or judgments, particularly when the situation is complex or difficult to understand.

meanings.meaning: To Get To The Bottom Of

meaning_mnemonic: 極める is "to carry to extremes." So, 極めて is something similar. It's used to refer to something that's <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary> _______.

You have <kanji>Europe</kanji> and <kanji>America</kanji>. This word refers to <vocabulary>Europe and America</vocabulary>. 

When people use 欧米 in Japan, they usually mean Western countries in general (<vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>), including North America and Western Europe. You'll often see it in news reports related to Western countries or in topics comparing Japanese and Western cultures, customs, or trends.
The <kanji>middle</kanji> part of <kanji>Europe</kanji> is <vocabulary>Central Europe</vocabulary>, wherever that is.

The 日 refers to "Japan" (It's the 日 of 日本). So, you have Japan and <kanji>Europe</kanji>, which makes this <vocabulary>Japan and Europe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese-European</vocabulary>.

日欧 is a fairly formal word commonly found in newspapers or official reports, where it’s often used for brevity when referring to Japan and Europe together, like in 日欧関係 (Japanese-European relations).

The <kanji>bay</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> isn't what you might think, it refers to <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary>, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary> if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.

When you <kanji>enter</kanji> an <kanji>inlet</kanji>, you've gone into the <vocabulary>inlet</vocabulary>. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. When <kanji>append</kanji>ing something, you basically want <vocabulary>to add something to</vocabulary> something, or <vocabulary>to include something</vocabulary> with it. 

添える means to add something alongside the main thing, often as a thoughtful touch to complement or support it. For example, you might say 添える when including a letter with a gift to add a personal touch, or when garnishing a dish with parsley to enhance its appearance. It's also used when you feel inclined to add a second hand to hold a bowl carefully.

Append and attach this document to your email. That’s called attachment. 添付 refers to the act of attaching something supplementary to another document, like attaching a file to an email or attaching a map to an invitation.

Things that are <kanji>strong</kanji> and <kanji>intense</kanji> are <vocabulary>very strong</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary>.

強烈 describes something so strong or intense that it leaves a lasting impression and is often <vocabulary>shocking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>striking</vocabulary>. It can refer to vividly bright colors, a blinding flash of light, extreme heat, or unusually bold or impactful comments.

If you're <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji> then you are <vocabulary>fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>.

猛烈 is used to describe <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary> things, like fierce storms, or actions done with great intensity, like working like mad. Its strong tone can feel a bit comical in casual use, so people also use it playfully to exaggerate things like how hungry they feel.

Your <kanji>fever</kanji> turns <kanji>violent</kanji> when you express your <vocabulary>fervent</vocabulary> feelings.

熱烈 is a relatively formal word that describes someone being fervently absorbed in something or someone and showing <vocabulary>ardent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>passionate</vocabulary> behavior, like 熱烈に応援する (support fervently).

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "<vocabulary>Fierce</vocabulary> ____" or "<vocabulary>Intense</vocabulary> _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is being done really fiercely or intensely.

猛 is used in compounds to emphasize fierceness or intensity, like 猛暑 (intense heat) or 猛勉強 (intense studying). It can also be used in expressions like 猛アプローチ (relentlessly pursuing someone romantically — a fierce "approach"). In casual uses like this, the strong tone is often intentionally goofy or comical.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>abbreviation</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to abbreviate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shorten</vocabulary>. In some cases, it can also mean <vocabulary>to omit</vocabulary> something for the sake of simplicity.

<kanji>Conserve</kanji> those letters with <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> and now you're <vocabulary>omitting</vocabulary> all the extra fluff! 

省略 is a relatively formal word used when you are intentionally <vocabulary>leaving out</vocabulary> something for the sake of brevity or simplicity, like an unneeded explanation or a long-winded greeting. It can also sometimes refer to the <vocabulary>abbreviation</vocabulary> of a word or phrase.
<kanji>Abbreviation</kanji> in <kanji>language</kanji> is an <vocabulary>abbreviation</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>acronym</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> version of a <kanji>diagram</kanji> doesn't include all the details. It's more like a <vocabulary>rough diagram</vocabulary> that shows only the essentials.

While 略図 can be used for any simplified diagram, it most commonly refers to a <vocabulary>rough map</vocabulary> that gives a basic overview of an area.

The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the <vocabulary>broad outline</vocabulary> of something bigger.

大略 is a relatively formal word commonly found in writing. It generally refers to a broader, rougher <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>overview</vocabulary> rather than a detailed summary.
痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is <vocabulary>a pain</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pain</vocabulary>.
痛み is "pain." 止める is "to stop." What stops pain if you use it? How about a <vocabulary>painkiller</vocabulary>.

眠い is "sleepy." The verb version of this is to sleep, or to fall asleep. yawn While 寝る can mean lying down or going to bed (not just sleeping), 眠る only refers to falling asleep or being in a state of sleep.

Some kind of <kanji>sleep</kanji>ing <kanji>medicine</kanji>? That's a <vocabulary>sleeping potion</vocabulary>!

眠り薬 is often found in storytelling contexts to refer to some kind of sleep-inducing concoction. But it can also be used as a less medical and more colloquial term for actual sleeping medication.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accumulate</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary>.

積もる is used to describe when something continuously collects or piles up over time, like snow on the ground or dust in a room. It can also be used in a more emotional way, like when feelings or thoughts quietly build up inside someone.

The <kanji>surface</kanji> that <kanji>accumulate</kanji>s into one area is a particular <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the area!

See how much liquid this <kanji>body</kanji> can <kanji>accumulate</kanji> in order to calculate its <vocabulary>volume</vocabulary>. It can be the body of a cup, the body of a bucket, or the body of a body. Whatever it is, the body accumulation represents its volume. (You know, how much space it takes up. Wasn't math class fun?)

You <kanji>examine</kanji> then <kanji>search</kanji>. These are the steps you take in order to perform a <vocabulary>lookup</vocabulary> of some kind. Or, as the case may be in modern times, do an <vocabulary>internet search</vocabulary>.

検索 originally referred to looking up information in books or using indexes and reference cards, like in a library. These days it's almost always used for digital and online searches.

You <kanji>search</kanji> then <kanji>pull</kanji> items from the <vocabulary>index</vocabulary> — you know, that list of keywords in alphabetical order at the end of a nonfiction book. Or in 五十音順 order, if you're fancy enough to be reading Japanese!
Things are <kanji>tense</kanji> and we have to <kanji>hurry</kanji>! This is quite the <vocabulary>urgent</vocabulary> <vocabulary>emergency</vocabulary>!

Things 締める (tighten), and eventually 切る (cut off), meaning you’ve reached the <vocabulary>deadline</vocabulary>! You can associate this with the feeling of your chest tightening once you approach the <vocabulary>due date</vocabulary> for something.

Note that you'll often encounter this written with okurigana like 締め切り as well. You might even see it with a simplified version of the 締 kanji written 〆切, which is relatively common in handwriting!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>servant</kanji> is a really important servant — you know, one who serves a king or some other political leader. What do we call a big, highfalutin servant who prances around doing jobs for the leader? A <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary>.

大臣 refers to high-ranking government officials who oversee ministries or departments, and it can be translated in different ways depending on the country and its political system, such as <vocabulary>cabinet minister</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>state minister</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>secretary of state</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>navigation</kanji> <kanji>method</kanji>s are the methods used for <vocabulary>navigation</vocabulary>.

航法 is a technical term for navigation, specifically referring to the techniques and methods used to guide a ship, aircraft, or spacecraft from one place to another.

<kanji>Navigation</kanji> in the <kanji>sky</kanji> is <vocabulary>aviation</vocabulary>. Vroom vroom, sky flying!

On its own 航空 refers to aviation, but you'll usually see it in compound words like 航空機 (aircraft) and 航空会社 (airline company).

Remember how 直行 is "nonstop"? Well, with 直航 it's the same thing, but it's only used for flights and boat trips, making this a <vocabulary>nonstop flight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>direct voyage</vocabulary>.

If there are <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji>s filling the <kanji>streets</kanji>, then you must have wandered into a <vocabulary>shopping district</vocabulary>. Hope you remembered to bring your wallet!

商店街 generally refers to a pedestrian-friendly street or area with lots of local shops and small businesses. Many 商店街 are covered with a roof, in which case they become <vocabulary>shopping arcade</vocabulary>s.

A <kanji>street</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is as wide as a street and a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It must be a <vocabulary>main road</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>highroad</vocabulary>!

Keep in mind 街道 isn't a generic term for main roads. It usually refers to important routes that connect different regions of Japan, especially those from the Edo period, like 日光街道 (Nikkōkaidō) and 中山道 (Nakasendō). But it can also refer to main roads with historical significance in other countries, like アッピア街道 (the Appian Way) in Italy or オックスフォード街道 (Oxford Street) in the UK.

In order to <kanji>diagnose</kanji> a patient, you must first go <vocabulary>to examine a patient</vocabulary>. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary>.

I will <kanji>diagnose</kanji> you by making an informed <kanji>guess</kanji> during this <vocabulary>medical exam</vocabulary>. 

診察 is what a doctor does when they take a look at you — a <vocabulary>medical examination</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>medical consultation</vocabulary>. Keep in mind this doesn't refer to specific medical tests you might undergo to help the doctor diagnose you. (For those, you'd use 検査.)

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stuffed</kanji>, this word means <vocabulary>to stuff in</vocabulary>, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know this because you're a <reading>mail</reading> (める) carrier, and you always have to stuff mail into people's packed mailboxes. Why don't these people check their mail more? It’s hard work trying to cram in all this junk mail!

詰める refers to tightly fitting something into an available space, like cramming clothes into a suitcase, putting jam into a jar, or even scooting over to make room, as you're squeezing yourself into a narrower space.

You <kanji>request</kanji> then you <kanji>request</kanji> again… Yep, this sounds like a <vocabulary>request</vocabulary to me.

請求 isn't just any old casual request — it's used when formally requesting something from another party. It often involves payment requests (like a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary>), but can also refer to asking for things like application forms or informational materials. It can even refer to the kind of <vocabulary>claim</vocabulary> you file in court.

Someone <kanji>request</kanji>s something, and you're the one <vocabulary>to take on</vocabulary> their request. Wow, how nice of you <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary> that request!

請ける is a formal word often used in business contexts to describe someone willingly accepting a job, task, or request. For example, you might use 請ける when taking on a new project or accepting customer orders.

To lend or to rent is 貸す. This is the noun version of that, used as a prefix. It is something that has been rented, a "<vocabulary>rental</vocabulary> ____," like a 貸しビル (rental office building) or 貸しボート (rental boat).

Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a <kanji>road</kanji>, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get lost</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>cabinet</kanji> <kanji>colleague</kanji>s are the <vocabulary>cabinet ministers</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cabinet secretaries</vocabulary>. They're the people in the Cabinet who are all colleagues with each other, making them <vocabulary>cabinet members</vocabulary>. Depending on the country, they're also called ministers or secretaries.

閣僚 is a formal term that refers to the collective group of high-ranking officials in a cabinet, but it can sometimes refer to an individual cabinet member as well.
When <kanji>the cabinet</kanji> meets for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> they are having a <vocabulary>cabinet meeting</vocabulary>. So governmenty.

You've learned 英 means "England," but it can also mean <kanji>excel</kanji>. So what kind of person excels at being <kanji>brave</kanji>? A <vocabulary>hero</vocabulary>!

英雄 is a relatively formal word often used to describe historical or legendary heroes, like William Wallace or King Arthur. In more casual contexts, like when talking about superheroes or referring to your dad as your hero, ヒーロー is more common.
The <kanji>Korea</kanji> <kanji>Country</kanji> is <vocabulary>Korea</vocabulary>, of course... well, <vocabulary>South Korea</vocabulary> that is.

Take the 日 from 日本 (Japan) and the 韓 from 韓国 (Korea), and stick 'em together to get an abbreviation for <vocabulary>Japan and South Korea</vocabulary>.

日韓 is a bit formal, so you'll usually see it in newspapers or reports referring to Japan and South Korea together. Think international relations and soccer matches.

You <kanji>like</kanji> it because it gives you an <kanji>odd</kanji> feeling in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. You don't quite know what it is you like, but that's because it's <vocabulary>curiosity</vocabulary> that you have.
<kanji>Odd</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji> are <vocabulary>odd numbers</vocabulary> (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).

That's very <kanji>odd</kanji> and <kanji>strange</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>bizarre</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary>.

奇妙 is often used in literature to describe something that feels unusually <vocabulary>strange</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>odd</vocabulary>. It describes something being an almost otherworldly quality, sparking curiosity because it's so bizarre.

If you <kanji>weave</kanji> a <kanji>thing</kanji>, you get a <vocabulary>textile</vocabulary>.

織物 primarily refers to woven <vocabulary>fabric</vocabulary>. It's often associated with traditional crafts, such as kimono textiles.

An <kanji>angry</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> comes out of you when you have <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary>.

怒気 looks simple, but it's a pretty advanced term more commonly used in literature, typically to describe a character's anger as expressed through their voices, facial expressions, attitudes, or the surrounding atmosphere.

When your <kanji>belly</kanji> has <kanji>decreased</kanji> in the amount of stuff inside it, you become <vocabulary>hungry</vocabulary>.

腹が減った is a casual way of saying <vocabulary>I'm hungry</vocabulary> in Japanese, often with a bit of a rough or masculine tone.

A <kanji>beckoning</kanji> <kanji>cat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beckoning cat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>maneki neko</vocabulary>. 

招き猫 are the cat statues believed to bring good luck and fortune to their owners. They're often placed in front of shops with one paw raised, as if beckoning and saying, "Hey, come on in!"

The kanji itself means <kanji>set up</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to set up</vocabulary>, as in establishing something in an orderly manner.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to assume a stance</vocabulary>, like taking a fighting posture, or to hold in preparation, such as a weapon, while preparing to engage in a fight.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>.

What makes it different from 訪ねる, though? With 訪ねる, you're going somewhere or visiting someone with a clear purpose. With 訪れる, the emphasis is on the act of visiting a place (and not a person), regardless of purpose. So, if you're simply saying that you're going to go visit the Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto, you could say 訪れる. On the other hand, if you're visiting the Kiyomizu Temple to discover something, or you're going to pay a visit to a teacher in Kyoto for some advice, you could use 訪ねる.

Those uses we just described for 訪れる are for when it is transitive. However, it can also be intransitive, if the action is done by something rather than someone. In that case, it means "to come", as in "winter comes" (冬が訪れる) or "peace comes" (平和が訪れる). 訪ねる, on the other hand, cannot be used in this way.

You <kanji>oversee</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> all that is in your domain. You are conducting <vocabulary>surveillance</vocabulary>.

監視 is the active <vocabulary>observation</vocabulary> of someone or something to ensure safety or compliance, or to detect suspicious activity. It can also refer to the people who carry out this <vocabulary>monitoring</vocabulary>, either directly or through the use of things like cameras.

The one who <kanji>oversee</kanji>s and <kanji>direct</kanji>s is the one who gives <vocabulary>supervision</vocabulary>. 

監督 refers to the act of supervising or to the person who supervises, such as the <vocabulary>head coach</vocabulary> of a sports team or a movie <vocabulary>director</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>.

I <kanji>recommend</kanji> this to you, so I'd like to <kanji>invite</kanji> you to try it. This is a <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>invitation</vocabulary>.

勧誘 means soliciting someone to buy a product or service or inviting them to join a group or activity, often in a pushy way. It's commonly used to describe what telemarketers and door-to-door evangelists do, or for students recruiting new members for extracurricular activities.
A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>board</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blackboard</vocabulary>.

<vocabulary>研修</vocabulary> is a training or study of some kind. If it's in your current <kanji>life</kanji> (生) that you are doing the training, then you are a <vocabulary>trainee</vocabulary>. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."

When you have "troublesome" (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as <vocabulary>spam</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spam mail</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>junk mail</vocabulary>. On a more technical level it's <vocabulary>unsolicited mail</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>draw near</kanji> to <kanji>give</kanji> something, you are probably giving a <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.

寄与 is a very formal word that refers to significant contributions in professional or official settings. It's commonly used in academic or business contexts to highlight how someone's work contributes to the advancement of a field of study or the growth of a company.

Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>politics</kanji> are in the hands of one <kanji>lady</kanji>: your <vocabulary>housekeeper</vocabulary>. Your housekeeper knows more about your house than you do — she cleans the place, after all — so it's only natural that she would control all its politics too.

Note that it's common to use the polite honorific さん when talking about a 家政婦さん!

If you <kanji>draw near</kanji> someone and <kanji>attach</kanji> some stuff to them, you're making a <vocabulary>donation</vocabulary>. They get to keep it, after all. 

寄付 means donating money, goods, or resources, usually for a charitable purpose.

Sometimes even though you think you're very much awake and <kanji>alive</kanji>, you can't help fall into a <kanji>sleep</kanji> and start <vocabulary>dozing off</vocabulary>. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything other than <vocabulary>nodding off</vocabulary>.

居眠り refers to light, unintentional sleep. It often happens when someone is supposed to stay awake but dozes off due to tiredness or boredom, like during a meeting, class, or (heaven forbid) while driving.

Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means <vocabulary>to anger someone</vocabulary>.

Verbs ending with an あせる sound (like 怒らせる) often mean that you're causing someone to feel, do, or experience something. So, 怒らせる means you make someone angry. You can remember this because you always make Russell (らせる) angry. No matter what you say, you seem to get on his nerves… you're just constantly angering this Russell guy.

The most <kanji>mysterious</kanji> thing that's <kanji>connected</kanji> to a house is the <vocabulary>entranceway</vocabulary>. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take off your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the <vocabulary>entryway</vocabulary> is then your only way out.

<kanji>Mysterious</kanji> <kanji>rice</kanji> is <vocabulary>unpolished rice</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>brown rice</vocabulary>. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>draw near</kanji>, so this verb version is <vocabulary>to draw near</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to stop by</vocabulary>, since stopping by a place is like drawing near it briefly, right?

Remember how you learned that 迷う means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well, when you feel like you've gone astray or gotten lost, you might act with <vocabulary>hesitation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>indecision</vocabulary>. You suddenly have <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary> about where to go or what to do next.

While 迷う can mean getting lost either physically or mentally, 迷い most often conveys an abstract sense of inner conflict or uncertainty, especially in decision making.

A <kanji>search</kanji> <kanji>search</kanji> is a more intense <vocabulary>search</vocabulary>, like the official <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary> for a missing person.

捜索 is a formal term often used by authorities or in news reports. It refers to an official search for a missing person or thing, and is commonly used in police investigations, rescue missions, or other organized searches.

The meaning of this word is the same as 任せる. Both words are pretty common, but 任す is slightly less common than 任せる.

Here's the mnemonic again, just in case you need a refresher:

If you pass a <kanji>duty</kanji> on to someone, that means you're going <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to that person, or you're going <vocabulary>to delegate something</vocabulary>. In other words, you're going <vocabulary>to leave something to</vocabulary> them, so that they do it for you.

If you want to <kanji>ride</kanji> in a <kanji>car</kanji>, the <kanji>ticket</kanji> you'll need is a <vocabulary>passenger ticket</vocabulary>.

乗車券 is primarily a <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary> for a train ride, so think of "car" here as a train car. It can also refer to tickets for other rides, like Ferris wheels, cable cars, ropeways, or certain buses that require a prior ticket purchase.

豚 comes from 豚肉 (pork), and カツ comes from the word "cutlet" and means just that. And a <kanji>pork</kanji> カツ is what any Japanese food fan will probably know as simply <vocabulary>tonkatsu</vocabulary>, a.k.a. <vocabulary>breaded pork cutlet</vocabulary>.

豚カツ is a Japanese pork cutlet coated in crispy panko breadcrumbs and deep-fried, making it light and crunchy. It's usually served with a tasty sweet-savory sauce. It's so good, you'll pig out on it!

Being <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>angry</kanji> means you're filled with <vocabulary>rage</vocabulary>, or for you to <vocabulary>be enraged</vocabulary>.

激怒 is a relatively formal word, often used in literature to describe someone flying into a rage or experiencing intense, uncontrollable anger. Therefore, you’ll frequently encounter this as a suru-verb in the form of 激怒する.

Things that happen <kanji>mutual</kanji>ly right <kanji>next</kanji> to each other are said <vocabulary>to happen successively</vocabulary>. In other words, <vocabulary>to happen one after another</vocabulary>.

相次ぐ is a relatively formal word often used in news reports to talk about multiple events or incidents happening one after another, usually in quick succession.

When you say humbly that you're requesting something, you're putting forward an application. 申請 refers to the process of officially applying for approval or permission, like ビザの申請 (application for a visa), ライセンスの申請 (application for a license), or 休暇の申請 (application for leave/vacation).

Remember how 夜更け meant "late at night"? Well, this is similar to that, but instead of referring to the time of night, it refers to the act of <vocabulary>staying up late</vocabulary>. 

夜更かし typically means staying up well past the time you know you should be going to bed. It's often associated with guilty pleasures like binge-watching TV shows or gaming.
